title: Specific heat of X and Z

content.description:
A student performs an experiment on samples of two unknown liquids. Each of the samples, which have the same mass, are placed into identical insulated cups. Identical masses of ice are added to each sample, and the ice melts completely. The student collects the information shown in the table.

Identity of sample
 Sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>X</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 Sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Mass of ice placed in sample
 <math alttext="6.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="6.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Temperature change of sample
 <math alttext="negative 5.0 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="negative 3.0 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Which of the following could explain why the temperature changes in samples <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>X</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were different?

choices.label: Sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were of the same substance, but the volume of sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was greater than that of sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were of the same substance, but the specific heat of sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was less than that of sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were of different substances, but the amount of energy needed to melt the ice in sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was greater than in sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were of different substances, and the specific heat of sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was less than sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: Sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> were of different substances, and the specific heat of sample <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was less than sample <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.B: Identify an appropriate theory, definition, or mathematical relationship to solve a problem.
